src.initializers module

class src.initializers.GlorotNormal[source]

Bases: Initializer

Glorot normal initializer.

Also called Xavier normal initializer. Draws samples from a normal distribution centered on 0 with stddev = sqrt(2/(x+y)) where x and y are the dimensions of the numpy array.

generate(x: int, y: int) → ndarray[source]

Return the initialized numpy array

Parameters:

  • x (int) – Size of first dimension of np.ndarray

  • y (int) – Size of second dimension of np.ndarray

Returns:

Initialized np.ndarray

Return type:

np.ndarray

class src.initializers.GlorotUniform[source]

Bases: Initializer

Glorot uniform initializer.

Also called Xavier uniform initializer. Draws samples from a uniform distribution within [-limit,limit] where limit = sqrt(6/(x+y)) where x and y are the dimensions of the numpy array.

generate(x: int, y: int) → ndarray[source]

Return the initialized numpy array

Parameters:

  • x (int) – Size of first dimension of np.ndarray

  • y (int) – Size of second dimension of np.ndarray

Returns:

Initialized np.ndarray

Return type:

np.ndarray

class src.initializers.HeNormal[source]

Bases: Initializer

He normal initializer.

Draws samples from a normal distribution centered on 0 with stddev = sqrt(2/(x)) where x is the first dimension of the numpy array.

class src.initializers.Initializer[source]

Bases: object

A base class for the numpy matrix initializers.

Initializers are used to set starting values to the weights and biases of the network layers. They can also be used to initialize any 1D or 2D numpy array. Most of the initializers found here can also be found in the Keras documentation here: https://keras.io/api/layers/initializers/

Any variables needed for a specific Initializer should be passed in the “__init__”. Values are generated in the “generate” method which takes y and y dimensions as a parameter. The generated numpy array will be of dimensions [x, y].

generate(x: int, y: int) → ndarray[source]

Virtual class to be overriden. Will raise NotImplementedError.

src.layer module

class src.layer.Dense(input_size: int, output_size: int, weight_init: ~src.initializers.Initializer = <src.initializers.GlorotNormal object>, bias_init: ~src.initializers.Initializer = <src.initializers.Zero object>)[source]

Bases: Layer

Dense layer with weights and biases.

backward(layer_input: ndarray, layer_output_grad: ndarray, learning_rate: float) → ndarray[source]

Perform the backward pass for the dense layer and apply SGD.

Parameters:

  • layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

  • layer_output_grad (np.ndarray) – Gradient of the output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

  • learning_rate (float) – Learning rate during backpropagation

Returns:

Gradient of the input matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

forward(layer_input: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Forward pass of the dense layer.

Output is calculated using the following formula: output = weights * input + bias

or: y = w*x + b

As this is a linear equation, Dense layer is also called a Linear layer.

Parameters:

layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

Returns:

Output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

reset()[source]

Reset weights and biases using the given initializer.

class src.layer.Dropout(ratio: float)[source]

Bases: Layer

Dropout layer which randomly sets certain activations in the layer to 0.

backward(layer_input: ndarray, layer_output_grad: ndarray, learning_rate: float) → ndarray[source]

Derivative of the dropout layer.

Simply, the nodes which were ignored during the forward pass should also be zeroed out during backward pass.

Parameters:

  • layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

  • layer_output_grad (np.ndarray) – Gradient of the output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

  • learning_rate (float) – Learning rate during backpropagation

Returns:

Gradient of the input matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

forward(layer_input: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Forward pass of the dropout layer

Generates a mask of 1’s and 0’s with a distribution dictated by the ratio. Ratio is the probability of 1 appearing and (1-ratio) is the probability of the 0 appearing.

Parameters:

layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

Returns:

Output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

reset()[source]

Reset the dropout values.

class src.layer.Layer[source]

Bases: object

Base class for layers.

Layers can be anything. They have to override forward and backward methods. Inside “backward” is a derivative of whatever operation happens inside “forward”. If weights and biases are present inside the layer, also apply their gradient inside the “backward” method. Additionally, they have to override the “reset” method if there are any weights and biases in the layer which are modified during backprop.

backward(layer_input: ndarray, layer_output_grad: ndarray, learning_rate: float) → ndarray[source]

Propagate the gradient without changing it

Backward method of the base layer class. Propagates the gradient matrix without changing it.

Parameters:

  • layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

  • layer_output_grad (np.ndarray) – Gradient of the output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

  • learning_rate (float) – Learning rate during backpropagation

Returns:

Gradient of the input matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

forward(layer_input: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Return output that is equal to the input.

Forward method of the base layer class. Merely outputs the input it gets.

Parameters:

layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

Returns:

Output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

reset()[source]

Reset layer weight and biases if any are present.

class src.layer.ReLU[source]

Bases: Layer

Layer containing the ReLU function.

backward(layer_input: ndarray, layer_output_grad: ndarray, learning_rate: float) → ndarray[source]

Apply the derivative of the ReLU function and propagate the gradient.

The derivative of the ReLu function is defined by the formula: d_relu(x) = 1 (x>0)

Or simpler: if x =< 0 -> out = 0 if x > 0 -> out = 1

So the ReLU derivative is just a step function.

Parameters:

  • layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

  • layer_output_grad (np.ndarray) – Gradient of the output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

  • learning_rate (float) – Learning rate during backpropagation

Returns:

Gradient of the input matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

forward(layer_input: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Return the output of the ReLU function for the given input.

The ReLU function is defined by the formula: relu(x) = maximum(0, x)

In other words, the output is: if x =< 0 -> out = 0 if x > 0 -> out = x

The output of the function is in the range [0,x]

Parameters:

layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

Returns:

Output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

class src.layer.Sigmoid[source]

Bases: Layer

Seems to cause exploding gradients. Layer containing the Sigmoid function.

backward(layer_input: ndarray, layer_output_grad: ndarray, learning_rate: float) → ndarray[source]

Apply the derivative of the sigmoid function and propagate the gradient.

The derivative of the sigmoid function is defined by the formula: d_sig(x) = sig(x) * (1 - sig(x))

Parameters:

  • layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

  • layer_output_grad (np.ndarray) – Gradient of the output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

  • learning_rate (float) – Learning rate during backpropagation

Returns:

Gradient of the input matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

forward(layer_input: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Return the output of the sigmoid function for the given input.

The sigmoid function is defined by the formula: sig(x) = 1 / (1 + e^(-x))

The output of the function is in the range [0,1]

Parameters:

layer_input (np.ndarray) – Input matrix of shape [batch,input_size]

Returns:

Output matrix of shape [batch,output_size]

Return type:

np.ndarray

reset()[source]

Reset the state of the neural network.

This method resets the internal state of the neural network, used before starting a new training session.

train(x_train: ~numpy.ndarray, y_train: ~numpy.ndarray, x_val: ~numpy.ndarray, y_val: ~numpy.ndarray, *, config: ~src.model.TrainConfig = <src.model.TrainConfig object>) → TrainReport[source]

Train the neural network.

This method trains the neural network using the provided training and validation data. It supports configurations for specifying the number of epochs, batch size, learning rate, and early stopping criteria.

Parameters:

  • x_train (np.ndarray) – Training input data.

  • y_train (np.ndarray) – Training target labels.

  • x_val (np.ndarray) – Validation input data.

  • y_val (np.ndarray) – Validation target labels.

  • config (TrainConfig) – Training configuration (optional).

Returns:

Training report.

Return type:

TrainReport

Starts training the given model using every config provided. Saves the training results and return them together with the configs.

src.utils module

class src.utils.DataAugmentor(shuffle: bool = True, translate_x: int | None = None, translate_y: int | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

Augment the dataset.

Available augmentations: - Translation on x-axis - Translation on y-axis

generate(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, *, generated_imgs_per_img: int = 1, keep_originals: bool = True) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Generate the augmented dataset.

Currently limited to translation by y-axis and x-axis. Generates a “generated_imgs_per_img” number of images per single image in input dataset. So if input dataset size is 60000, and “generated_imgs_per_img” is 2, with “keep_originals” set to True, returns the dataset of size 180000. With “keep_originals” set to False, it would return a dataset of size 120000.

Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray) – Input images

  • y (np.ndarray) – Input labels

  • generated_imgs_per_img (int) – How many images are generated per one image inside the dataset

  • keep_originals (bool) – Keep the original un-augmented images inside the dataset or not

Returns:

Augmented dataset

Return type:

tuple[np.ndarray,np.ndarray]

Will raise NotImplementedError.

  • y_target (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing expected values in the form of a one-hot vector

class src.utils.SoftmaxCrossentropy[source]

Bases: LossFunction

Softmax Cross-entropy loss.

As cross-entropy loss is used to calculate the difference between two probability distributions, it naturally works well with softmax. Softmax converts logits to a probability distribution vector, and we use that to calculate the cross-entropy between the model’s predictions and the expected output.

derivative(y_pred: ndarray, y_target: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Return the derivative of the softmax cross-entropy function

Simplification of the softmax cross-entropy derivative due to the fact that we use a one-hot vector during the calculation of cross-entropy. As the one-hot vector contains zeros for incorrect classes, they do not contribute to the loss. Derivative of softmax cross-entropy is simply subtracting 1 from the softmax value at the index of the correct class. Explained in-depth here: https://www.michaelpiseno.com/blog/2021/softmax-gradient/

Parameters:

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing predicted values from the model

  • y_target (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing expected values in the form of a one-hot vector

Returns:

Derivative of cross-entropy of shape [batch, n_classes]. Used for the start of backpropagation

Return type:

np.ndarray

loss(y_pred: ndarray, y_target: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Return cross-entropy loss.

Parameters:

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing predicted values from the model

  • y_target (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing expected values in the form of a one-hot vector

Returns:

Cross-entropy loss of shape [batch, n_classes]

Return type:

np.ndarray

class src.utils.SquaredError[source]

Bases: LossFunction

Square error loss function.

Square error is calculated as: Error = (y_pred - y_target)^2

derivative(y_pred: ndarray, y_target: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Return a derivative of the square error.

Return a np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] that represents the derivative of the square error function. Square error derivative is calculated as: Error = 2*(y_pred - y_target)

Parameters:

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing predicted values from the model

  • y_target (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing expected values in the form of a one-hot vector

Returns:

Square error derivative of shape [batch, n_classes]. Used for the start of backpropagation

Return type:

np.ndarray

loss(y_pred: ndarray, y_target: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Return a np.ndarray containing square error values of the same dimensions as input.

Parameters:

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing predicted values from the model

  • y_target (np.ndarray) – np.ndarray of shape [batch,n_classes] containing expected values in the form of a one-hot vector

Returns:

Square error of shape [batch, n_classes]

Return type:

np.ndarray

src.utils.one_hot(a: int, n: int) → ndarray[source]

Return a one-hot vector of size “n” for a given value “a”.

For example: a = 3; n = 7; out = np.ndarray([0,0,1,0,0,0,0])

Parameters:

  • a (int) – value that the one-hot vector will represent

  • n (int) – one-hot vector size, or number of classes

Returns:

one-hot vector as a numpy array

Return type:

np.ndarray

src.utils.see_if_guess_is_correct(y_pred: ndarray, y_target: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Compare the model prediction and the expected label.

Returns an array of [0,1] values where 1 means that the guess is correct, and 0 means that the guess is incorrect

Parameters:

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – given prediction

  • y_target (np.ndarray) – expected label

Returns:

Array of [0,1] values where 1 means that the guess is correct

Return type:

np.ndarray

src.utils.shuffle_x_y(x: ndarray, y: ndarray) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Shuffle the dataset split into x and y.

Can shuffle any array of same length, but here it is used to apply the same shuffle to the x and y of the MNIST dataset

Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray) – Dataset imgs

  • y (np.ndarray) – Dataset labels

Returns:

Shuffled arrays

Return type:

tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray]

src.utils.train_val_splitter(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, ratio: float) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]

Split the dataset into train and validation.

If ratio is 0.8, then 80% of the dataset will be the “train” set, and 20% will become the “validation” set. Shuffles the dataset.

Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray) – Dataset imgs

  • y (np.ndarray) – Dataset labels

  • ratio (float) – train and validation ratio

Returns:

split dataset

Return type:

tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray]
